|footnotes = }} The 'Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research
Organisation' ('CSIRO') is the national government body for scientific research
in Australia. It was founded in 1926 originally as the Advisory Council of
Science and Industry.

Research highlights include the invention of atomic absorption spectroscopy,
development of the first commercially successful polymer banknote, the invention
of the insect repellent in Aerogard and the introduction of a series of
biological controls into Australia, such as the introduction of myxomatosis and
rabbit calicivirus which causes rabbit haemorrhagic disease for the control of
rabbit populations. CSIRO's research into ICT technologies has resulted in
advances such as the Panoptic search engine (now known as Funnelback)
and Annodex.

In October 2005, the journal ''Nature'' announced CSIRO scientists had developed
near-perfect rubber from resilin, the elastic protein which gives fleas their
jumping ability and helps insects fly. {{cite journal |author=Elvin CM, Carr
AG, Huson MG, Maxwell JM, Pearson RD, Vuocolo T, Liyou NE, Wong DC, Merritt DJ,
Dixon NE |date=13 October 2005 |title=Synthesis and properties of crosslinked
recombinant pro-resilin |journal=''Nature'' |volume=437 |issue=7061
|pages=999â1002
|url=http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v437/n7061/full/nature04085.html |accessdate=2006-04-
24 |doi=10.1038/nature04085 |pmid=16222249 }} On 19 August 2005, CSIRO and
the University of Texas at Dallas announced they were able to make transparent
carbon nanotube sheets that will bring carbon nanotube products to the masses.
